En esta charla voy a hacer un recorrido por algunas de las principales características del lenguaje y ponerlas frente a frente con Groovy. Veremos ventajas e inconvenientes de las dos aproximaciones y espero que salgáis con bastante ideas de cómo es el lenguaje.

event.speaker: Bob Dahlberg
event.title: Jfokus 2019
event.subject: Quickie: Pitfalls when mixing Kotlin & Java
event.description:
I've had my fair share of android projects being converted to Kotlin from Java and I thought I'd share the lessons I've learned doing so. There are a few subtle pitfalls that are very easy to fall into.

So this is gonna be a quickie about my best practices and how to avoid doing the same mistakes I've made and seen

event.speaker: Justin D Lee
event.title: Jfokus 2019
event.subject: Kotlin is as awesome as you've heard. Here's why.
event.description: Most presentations introducing a new language are really just language tours. A lot of interesting language features are shown but it's not always clear why one would choose to adopt that new language. This presentation looks at a number of interesting features of the language and ecosystem that are more interesting than just a fancy new for loop. No one switch languages because of a for loop. So we'll look at a number of "big ticket" features of the language and ecosystem that do more to distinguish Kotlin than mere syntax sugar alone can provide. It will reasonably fast paced as we try to cover as many interesting tidbits as we can get through.

event.speaker: Anton Arhipov
event.title: Jfokus 2019
event.subject: Kotlin DSL in 45 minutes
event.description:
Learn how to create type-safe and statically typed DSLs in Kotlin. Uncover the language features that makes DSL creation possible. Well take a look at a few practical examples and create a simple DSL ourselves.

The session starts with an introduction to DSL related Kotlin language features. Next, we create a simple DSL in a live coding session and then continue adding expressiveness and language features. We cover a number of examples, like JSON or XML builders, data binding, configuration & template engines.

event.speaker: Roman Elizarov
event.title: GOTO Conference 2019
event.subject: Asynchronous Programming with Kotlin
event.description: This workshop covers asynchronous programming in Kotlin using coroutines. It starts with basics of asynchronous programming and its differences from blocking code and introduces concepts of suspending functions and coroutines. Dealing with the ecosystem of blocking code on JVM is covered in depth as well as best practices for managing cancellation of asynchronous operations. The workshop also covers more advanced topics of concurrent decomposition of work via futures, deep dive into coroutine contexts and includes an overview of Communication Sequential Process (CSP) approach and channels.

event.speaker: Marek Multarzyński
event.title: Kotlin Night Warsaw
event.subject: Interoperability with Kotlin
event.description: In this presentation I would like to introduce the audience to the Kotlin Native compilation. We will determine its reasonable use. I will show the result of Kotlin Native compilation on many platforms. We will make a comparison between Kotlin Native approach and native solutions.

event.speaker: Krzysztof Romanowski
event.title: Kotlin Night Warsaw
event.subject: The price we all pay. Does Kotlin slow down our code?
event.description:
Kotlin, as well as other languages like Scala or Groovy is developed (echm, hacked, eckm) over JVM. We all enjoy features like extension methods or strict null management that does not have corresponding functionalities native to JVM. How does that affect performance?

Let’s run some benchmarks!

event.speaker: Sean Mcquillan
event.title: Chicago Roboto 2019
event.subject: Launching Into Coroutines
event.description: Kotlin coroutines are a new way to manage async operations on Android. Stable with Kotlin 1.3 now is a great time to explore using coroutines in your app. In this talk you’ll learn about the history coroutines, how they work in Kotlin, and effective patterns for using coroutines on Android. The talk will also cover how to avoid common pitfalls and mistakes with using coroutines. After this talk you will have a good understanding of Kotlin coroutines and how to effectively use them on Android!

event.speaker: Huyen Tue Dao
event.title: Chicago Roboto 2019
event.subject: Dissecting the stdlib II
event.description: One of the best places to learn idiomatic Kotlin is the stdlib. Now I don’t mean just using the stdlib but going to the source, literally. In this session, we’ll look at some of the methods and tools inside the stdlib and dig into how they’re written to reveal intermediate to advanced language features, slick syntax and conventions, and high-level abstractions to help you write more fluent objects and interfaces. We’ll also take a few glances at the underlying bytecode to understand how and why the features work the way they do.

event.speaker: Ronan Doyle
event.title: South East Tech Meetup
event.subject: Kotlin vs Java for Android
event.description: While Kotlin can be used to develop server-side, web and native OS applications, this talk will focus on highlighting some of the benefits of using Kotlin over Java when developing Android applications.

event.speaker: Danny Preussler
event.title: MobileTechCon
event.subject: Kotlin vs. Java
event.description:
Geht es nach Google, ist Kotlin die Zukunft der Android-Entwicklung. Erst vor etwas mehr als einem Jahr als „First-Class Citizen“ offiziell für die Android Plattform freigegeben, setzen heute bereits mehr als 25% der Top 1000 Android Anwendungen aus dem Play Store auf Kotlin. Und noch wichtiger: Die Zufriedenheit der Entwickler liegt laut Umfrage bei 97% und damit deutlich über dem vergleichbaren Wert für Java.

Der Grund hierfür liegt klar auf der Hand. Die speziell für die Entwicklung von Android Apps geschaffene Sprache ist die direkte Antwort auf viele Probleme, die sich durch die Verwendung von Java im Android-Umfeld ergeben. Sie vereint dabei das Beste aus objektorientierter und funktionaler Programmiersprache und unterstützt so die Entwickler optimal mit Inter-Operabilität, Sicherheit und Tool Support.

Der Workshop stellt Kotlin aus Sicht eines Android-Entwicklers vor und zeigt, welche Vorteile die Verwendung der neuen Programmiersprache mit sich bringen kann. Natürlich gehen wir dabei auch auf mögliche Migrationsszenarien und das Zusammenspiel von Java und Kotlin ein.

event.speaker: Joost Heikoop
event.title: Brabant.scala
event.subject: Kotlin vs. Java
event.description: We have almost 20 years of Scala experience between us and have experience with many other languages. Recently we have jumped onto Kotlin, because it look very promising as Java competitor. Of course there is no one size fits all solution. We will show how the two languages compare and explain why and when, you should pick one over the other. Or maybe should consider some else all together.

event.speaker: Marharyta Nedzelska
event.title: Voxxed Days Zürich
event.subject: Building microservices with Kotlin and gRPC

event.speaker: Pavel Finkelstein
event.title: JUG.ru
event.subject: Kotlin два года в проде и ни единого разрыва

event.speaker: Ben Boral
event.title: Austin Kotlin Meetup
event.subject: Ktor "a Kotlin framework for building asynchronous servers and clients in connected systems."
event.description: This month, Ben Boral will present a REST API he is building using Ktor. This talk will explain how to build a REST API in Kotlin with Ktor assuming zero prior Ktor knowledge.

event.speaker: Mohit Sarveiya
event.title: New York Kotlin Meetup
event.subject: Dissecting Coroutines
event.description: 2019 maybe be the year of Kotlin coroutines. What is a coroutine anyway? A coroutine is an instance of a state machine and a suspending function defines the state machine. What does that mean? Join me in this talk as we will explore the ins and out of coroutines. We will dive deep into channels, actors and the reactive streams modules. We’ll also look at their usage to solve common async problems in Android.

event.speaker: Brent Watson
event.title: New York Kotlin Meetup
event.subject: Advanced Kotlin
event.description: Brent will be giving the talk that he presented at droidcon nyc and droidcon sf on "Advanced Kotlin". We'll cover some of the more advanced features of Kotlin in this talk such as delegates, annotation use-site targets, tailrec, reflection, and much more.

event.speaker: Sébastien Deleuze
event.title: The Brussels Java User Group
event.subject: Spring Boot with Kofu and Coroutines
event.description:
This presentation will give me the opportunity to present the upcoming official support of coroutines in Spring (Framework, Boot, Data) as well as Kofu, the Kotlin DSL, developed within the the Spring Fu incubator that I started a few months ago, which goal is to configure Spring Boot in a more explicit as well as more efficient manner.

My live coding will demonstrate how to develop a Spring Boot application with Kofu by using the new Coroutine API's from WebFlux and Spring Data R2DBC (Reactive SQL).

We will also compare Reactive API's versus Coroutines (pros and cons) to help you make informed decisions.

event.speaker: Dennis Dierkes, Ruben Gees
event.title: Bielefelder Kotlin User Group
event.subject: Sealed Classes, Reified Generics and Ktor
event.description:
Den Anfang macht Ruben (https://github.com/rubengees) mit Sealed Classes. Sealed Classes erweitern Enums um alle Funktionalitäten einer traditionellen Klasse und sind besonders nützlich im Zusammenhang mit Generics und dem speziellen Typ Nothing.

Anschließend erzählt Robin (https://github.com/roschlau) etwas über Reified Generics, welche im Gegensatz zu Java die Typinformationen auch innerhalb der Funktion verfügbar machen, was zu lesbarerem Code führt.

Den Schluss macht Dennis (https://github.com/deen13) mit Ktor, einem Framework zur Erstellung webbasierter API's mit minimalem Aufwand.

event.speaker: Ellen Shapiro
event.title: Appdevcon 2019
event.subject: Kotlin/Native: The Good, The Bad, and the Ugly
event.description: The promise of write-once-run-everywhere has haunted native mobile developers since the first time someone whispered the words “phone gap”. But what if there was a way to have cross-platform development with a modern, type-safe language? JetBrains is trying to make this happen with Kotlin/Native, which compiles to LLVM bytecode, and can run on iOS, Android, and even the web. Learn more about some of the benefits of working with Kotlin/Native, some of the drawbacks, and a few of the (current) potential dealbreakers when it comes to using this exciting new technology in a real app.

event.speaker: Sean McQuillan
event.title: GOTO Conference 2019
event.subject: Embracing the Future in a Multi-Platform World: A Kotlin Story
event.description:
So you know Kotlin, but you aren’t sure you’re utilizing it to its full potential across platforms?

If you’re not sure about what Coroutines really have to offer or if you want to share your business logic between Android and other platforms, this session is your next step to becoming a Kotlin expert and your lesson on how to thrive in a multi-language world.

In this session, you’ll learn how to write a multiplatform utility class and how Coroutines can live next to RxJava.

event.speaker: Fabio Collini
event.title: GDG DevFest Pisa 0.1
event.subject: From Java to Kotlin beyond Alt+Shift+Cmd+K
event.description: Kotlin is a first-class language for Android development since Google I/O 2017. And it’s here to stay! Thanks to Android Studio it’s really easy to introduce Kotlin in an existing project, the configuration is trivial and then we can convert Java classes to Kotlin using a Alt+Shift+Cmd+K. But the new syntax is the just beginning, using Kotlin we can improve our code making it more readable and simpler to write. In this talk we’ll see how to use some Kotlin features (for example data classes, collections, coroutines and delegates) to simplify Android development comparing the code with the equivalent “modern” Java code. It’s not fair to compare Kotlin code with plain Java 6 code so the Java examples will use lambdas and some external libraries like RxJava and AutoValue.

event.speaker: Roberto Orgiu
event.title: GDG DevFest Pisa 0.1
event.subject: EAsync Kotlin
event.description: Writing async code is never easy, but nowadays we have many solutions. One approach would be to use RxJava and its schedulers but... have you heard of Kotlin Coroutines? Join us and let's see how good they are today!

event.speaker: James Mark Coggan
event.title: GDG DevFest Pisa 0.1
event.subject: How to test your Android Things code in a clean way with Kotlin
event.description: Android things gives you the ability to connect all those Internet of things devices you have around all together. But how can you test it? In this talk you will learn in a practical way how to structure your Android Things project so you can write proper unit tests that don’t depend on your sensors, actuators or the Android framework.

event.speaker: Fabio Collini, Roberto Orgiu
event.title: GDG DevFest Pisa 0.1
event.subject: Kotlin Codelab Part 2 - Extra Registration needed!
event.description: Kotlin è un linguaggio di programmazione utilizzabile su piattaforma JVM e, dall’ultimo Google I/O, supportato ufficialmente su Android. Durante il Codelab sarà mostrato come convertire a Kotlin una app Android scritta in Java. L'app è composta da sei classi Java, le classi saranno convertite una ad una in Kotlin analizzando la sintassi di questo linguaggio e i vari costrutti utilizzabili. L'esempio è disponibile qui: https://github.com/fabioCollini/KotlinCodelab IMPORTANTE: Visto il numero ridotto di posti, per questo codelab é obbligatorio registarsi qui: http://bit.ly/dfpi17-codelab

event.speaker: Nagy Bence
event.title: Kotlin Budapest User Group
event.subject: Type Safety with Inline Classes
event.description: From measuring elapsed time to querying database objects, representing different concepts with primitive values is a common practice in many programming languages. Luckily, Kotlin’s new inline classes enable us to accurately represent these concepts in a type-safe and efficient manner.

event.speaker: Voros Gyula
event.title: Kotlin Budapest User Group
event.subject: Micronaut + Kotlin
event.description: Micronaut is a modern, JVM-based, full-stack framework for building modular, easily testable microservice and serverless applications. And it pairs amazingly well with Kotlin - Gyula is here to tell you all about it.

event.speaker: Matt Berteaux
event.title: Kotlin Utah User Group
event.subject: Intro to Ktor
event.description: This month we are going to learn about Ktor a "framework for quickly creating connected applications in Kotlin with minimal effort."

event.speaker: Daniel Gruici
event.title: Seattle Kotlin
event.subject: Statefulness is fun! Except when it gets cumbersome.
event.description: We will be talking about how being stateful in your applications can be useful (especially with Kotlin's help), some pitfalls and not so great stuff that can come up as you go, as well as how it greatly benefits testing for both UI and Unit tests.

event.speaker: Ravi Subramanian
event.title: Seattle Kotlin
event.subject: A deep dive into adb
event.description: What does `adb lolcat` do? A deep dive into adb

event.speaker: Jan Völker
event.title: Kotlin User Group Düsseldorf
event.subject: How to write an interpreter in Kotlin
event.description: In this talk we'll show you how to write a simple interpreter from scratch. No dependencies, no tricks just pure kotlin.

event.speaker: Yassine Benabbas
event.title: Lille Android User Group
event.subject: Les nouveautés de Kotlin 1.3 en Live Coding
event.description:
Découvrons ensemble les nouveautés de Kotlin 1.3. Au programme on verra notamment les inline classes, les contrats et la les coroutines qui ont été stabilisées.

Live coding signifie que tout sera illustré avec du code et un IDE (IntelliJ). Donc c’est garanti 0% slides.

event.speaker: Salomon Brys
event.title: Lille Android User Group
event.subject: Kotlin pour Android, iOS et le Web
event.description:
Kotlin est un des langages officiels pour le développement Android, et il est maintenant officiellement supporté par plusieurs framework backends comme Spring. Saviez vous que vous pouvez utiliser Kotlin pour compiler pour iOS via LLVM ou pour le web via JS ?

Durant cette présentation, je montrerai comment créer une application mobile qui tourne sur Android, sur iOS et sur le web tout en restant fidèle à chaque plateforme.

event.speaker: Ohad Shai
event.title: KotlinTLV
event.subject: Playing with Kotlin Workshop
event.description: We will meet again, with a different format. This time we will hold a workshop so please bring your laptop. In this workshop, we will implement the game of 2048 together. The exercise is originally a part of the 'Kotlin for Java Developers' course that is taught by JetBrains. We will have IntelliJ IDE Ultimate licenses as prizes.

event.speaker: Krzysztof Korbacz
event.title: Kraków Kotlin User Group
event.subject: Lesson learned - Kotlin on backend
event.description:
Have you recently wondered if this new backend project is a good moment to jump into Kotlin, but all you know about it was those blog posts and presentations saying how cool is it?

Maybe it is good idea to ask someone brave or stupid enough who has already done it? Then here we are to tell you our story of transformation from Java backend devs to Kotlin backend developers.

We will tell you what pitfalls we see in Kotlin and which of its features we appreciate the most. We will walk you through the recipes we gathered in our last project. Last but not least we will tell you if we would choose Kotlin again, knowing what we know today :)

event.speaker: Paweł Pyzik
event.title: Kraków Kotlin User Group
event.subject: Can your team benefit from migrating to Kotlin?
event.description: After talk we would like to invite to you to discussion about benefits and drawback of switching from java to Kotlin. We will share stories from people who managed to convince their product owners to taka a risk of shifting to Kotlin.:)

event.speaker: Simon Wirtz
event.title: Kotlin User Group Düsseldorf
event.subject: Coroutines - Simple Concurrency with Kotlin
event.description:
This talk will give an overview of Kotlin's approach to coroutines and how they help you structure your code. Let's see what coroutines are, how they look like and how they support us in writing concurrent code for the JVM, JavaScript and other platforms.

It has never been a better time to get started with Kotlin coroutines as JetBrains has just released them in a 1.0 version.

event.speaker: Marcin Moskala
event.title: Kotlin Warsaw by Kt. Academy
event.subject: Klub dyskusji programistycznej
event.description: Spotkanie w czasie którego będziemy dyskutować na tematy związane z programowaniem. Głównym celem jest rozwój własnego zrozumienia problemów i koncepcji programistycznych, oraz wypracowywanie lepszych praktyk dla programistów. Dodatkowo chcemy poprawić nasze umiejętności sprawnego artykuowania swoich myśli oraz prowadzenia dyskusji programistycznej.

event.speaker: Ilmir Usmanov
event.title: Belarus Kotlin User Group
event.subject: Kotlin Coroutines: Deep Dive
event.description: Ильмир расскажет о том, как корутины устроены внутри: какие преобразования делает компилятор, чтобы синхронный код превратить в ассинхронный; как на низком уровне представлены корутины и что на самом деле делают функции suspendCoroutine и resume.

event.speaker: Ruslan Ibragimov
event.title: Belarus Kotlin User Group
event.subject: Undertow
event.description: Руслан расскажет о своем опыте использования Undertow: примеры использования, как подружить корутины с undertow и сравнит его с более известными Spring и Ktor.

event.speaker: Dmitry Savinov
event.title: Java Jam
event.subject: Kotlin Contracts
event.description: Контракты — это новая экспериментальная фича в Kotlin 1.3. Поговорим о том, что такое контракты в Котлине и с чем их едят. Посмотрим на то, что уже можно потрогать руками — как в стабильном режиме, так и в экспериментальном. В конце немного обсудим текущее направление исследований в этой области.

event.speaker: Anton Arhipov
event.title: Tallinn DevOps Meetup
event.subject: Kotlin DSL in under an hour

event.speaker: Matt Ellis
event.title: dotnetsheff
event.subject: Kotlin for the curious
event.description:
Interested in Kotlin? And why not - it’s a pragmatic language designed to remove ceremony, solve real world problems and still feel familiar to newcomers. It can target the JVM, Android, JavaScript and native code, even running on iOS. That’s a lot of reach for a single programming language.

In this talk, we’ll go on a high level, introductory tour of Kotlin - how to get up and running, what Kotlin looks like, and how to write idiomatic, concise code - functional or object oriented. We’ll look at data classes, top level and first class functions, inlining, null safety and more, including the design decisions behind some of the language choices. We’ll see how you can build DSLs, with examples from Android and HTML, and look at how we can build multi-platform projects. And we’ll take a look at coroutines, Kotlin’s answer to C#’s async/await.

event.speaker: Marharyta Nedzelska
event.title: Warsaw Cloud Native Meetup
event.subject: Building Microservices with Kotlin and gRPC
event.description: Microservice architecture is now a huge trend. All big organizations with millions of users are doing microservices. This means they have lots of channels of communication between services and need to send and get much data. At some point, you can find yourself in a situation where your current approach doesn’t provide you with efficient communications, you pay more, wait for more, lose more etc. Maybe it’s time to look at gRPC… In this talk, we will cover the basics of gRPC, protocol buffers, and its usage. We will try to understand its pros and cons and where this approach could be used. We will also compare this approach with the alternatives. The most interesting about this talk is that we will have lots of practice. We will learn how to write .proto files, how to make effective communication between your microservices, and of course, write much code (in Kotlin)

event.speaker: Mike Patterson
event.title: Denver Droids (aka Denver Android Developers Group)
event.subject: Coroutines: Kotlin's Flexible Async Approach
event.description:
Asynchronous programming is impossible to avoid in Android development unless your app is quite simple. Any networking or database calls require background threads to avoid blocking the UI, which could create ANR (Application Not Responding) bugs.

The Android framework provides AsyncTasks, which can be unwieldy. Some app developers use 3rd party libraries like RxJava to handle threading, which can involve a steep learning curve.

Coroutines provide a few advantages over these, but most importantly coroutines make asynchronous code read like synchronous code. With the release of Kotlin v1.3, coroutines are now stable. Come to Denver Droids and learn about the advantages, the how-to, and some best practices around coroutines.

event.speaker: mhidaka
event.title: DroidKaigi 2019
event.subject: Understanding Kotlin Coroutines: コルーチンで進化するアプリケーション開発
event.description:
Kotlin Coroutinesは非同期処理をシンプルに記述できるKotlinの言語機能です。実験的な機能としてこれまでも提供されてきましたがKotlin 1.3で正式にリリース予定です。

Androidの誕生から10年たちアプリの利用シーンが増えた結果、アプリ開発の複雑さも増してきています。開発者はアプリの性質に合わせてMVVMをはじめとしたアーキテクチャとArchitecture Components（AAC）など複雑性を解消するライブラリを組み合わせ、実装上の課題を解決してきました。

本セッションでは新登場のCoroutinesを既存のアプリケーションへ適用する方法と導入するメリットを中心に解説します。

Coroutines の本質を理解することはアーキテクチャをよりシンプルに保ちます。そして言語機能の追加がアプリ開発現場に与える影響を考察していきます。

設計・開発の効率化といえば、これまで多くの場合、ライブラリの導入がメインでした。しかしアプリの複雑性が増加するにつれて多数のライブラリを導入しつづけることは開発者に多くの知識を要求し、イニシャルコストの増加に繋がります。言語そのものの力を理解することでコストを下げ、より素早い開発を実現できます。

本セッションはアプリ開発で実践できるよう、なじみのあるアーキテクチャを通じてCoroutinesを学んでいきます。 聞き終わったときには、AACなどモダンなライブラリのなかで効率的な非同期処理に対応する方法を習得できます

event.speaker: Sean McQuillan
event.title: GOTO Chicago 2019
event.subject: Embracing the Future in a Multi-Platform World: A Kotlin Story
event.description:
So you know Kotlin, but you aren’t sure you’re utilizing it to its full potential across platforms?

If you’re not sure about what Coroutines really have to offer or if you want to share your business logic between Android and other platforms, this session is your next step to becoming a Kotlin expert and your lesson on how to thrive in a multi-language world.

In this session, you’ll learn how to write a multiplatform utility class and how Coroutines can live next to RxJava.

event.speaker: Paulien van Alst
event.title: GOTO Amsterdam 2019
event.subject: Upgrade Time: Choose Java 11 or the “other” one… Kotlin
event.description: Most of the Java applications are written in Java 8 nowadays and people are looking around to upgrade to Java 11 or even migrating to Kotlin. Both are promoted as the new way to go and both have their own strengths and weaknesses. Upgrading to Java 11 might be an obvious next safe step to do. But what if you could migrate to Kotlin with the same effort? This would bring you additional advantages like: data classes, very concise list manipulations, extension functions, DSL's and even more to get your code more readable and maintainable. Considering the Kotlin migration, the first questions that pop up are: What are the wise steps to take and where to start? Some experiences and thoughts answering these questions will be shared during this live coding session.

event.speaker: Saul Molinero
event.title: Vigo Android Developer Group
event.subject: Por qué de debería conocer Kotlin

event.speaker: Marcelo Olivas
event.title: Miami JVM Group
event.subject: Kotlin for Java Developers
event.description:
An introduction to the Kotlin language and why it is getting so much attention. In this talk, we will learn some of the advantages and features of the language.

The growth of Kotlin as an Android development language has been explosive. If you are developing for Android devices, you need to become comfortable with the language, both for native development and because more and more tutorials and support libraries are adopting it. Join us to gain an understanding of Kotlin fundamentals.

event.speaker: Rohit Basu
event.title: DeveloperWeek 2019
event.subject: Go - Rust - Scala - Kotlin, What Should I Learn Next?
event.description: have been coding in Java & Javascript for many years now and I want to learn something new. If I had to pick 1 Systems Programming and 1 Applications Programming language, which should/would that be. In this talk, I will compare go, rust, scala, kotlin and show how easy/difficult it is to write the first `Hello World` in these languages. We will look at the pros and cons of these 4 languages and will try to pick winners.

event.speaker: Nick Capurso
event.title: 360|AnDev 2019
event.subject: Kotlin Coroutines: An Intro to Practical Use on Android
event.description:
Asynchronous programming has always been a challenging problem for Android developers. Any good solution has to gracefully handle errors, cancellation, chaining multiple actions together, handle thread swapping, and much more.

Kotlin’s coroutines are yet another option for asynchronous programming. However, unlike other popular contenders, coroutines meet all the previously mentioned requirements out-of-the-box, have a gentler learning curve, and don’t require you to write an absurd amount of boilerplate.

That said, learning any new asynchronous solution takes time and often comes with a period of trial-and-error until you have all the nuances figured out. Get a jumpstart on coroutines:

(1) Lessen the learning curve by getting the subtleties of coroutines out of the way early (2) Learn how to work coroutines into an existing app: easy places to start transitioning, interop with existing libraries, and reusing existing threading constructs (3) Learn how to easily support error handling, cancellation, and task chaining (4) Learn how to unit test coroutines

Get a head start on coroutines in your apps and easily write, test, and maintain asynchronous code like never before!

event.speaker: Joshua Lamson
event.title: 360|AnDev 2019
event.subject: Kotlinize your Canvas
event.description:
When you’re creating a new View to display some complex data, it’s easy for the number of View objects you’re using to get out of control. Between elaborate shapes, shaders/colors, and text in specific places and orientations, using only Android Views and layouts can turn your layout into a dense, complicated mess. Luckily, there’s a better way to add all your customizations. What you need is a blank Canvas! (Literally, android.graphics.Canvas).

In this session, we’ll delve into the details of using a Canvas to display anything you need in a truly custom way, explaining it all through simple examples written in Kotlin. You’ll leave this talk knowing how override the behavior of View, ViewGroup, and Drawable to draw custom shapes, paths, and text on the Canvas.

event.speaker: Marcin Moskala
event.title: Kotlin Warsaw by Kt. Academy
event.subject: Klub dyskusji programistycznej
event.description: Spotkanie w czasie którego będziemy dyskutować na tematy związane z programowaniem. Głównym celem jest rozwój własnego zrozumienia problemów i koncepcji programistycznych, oraz wypracowywanie lepszych praktyk dla programistów. Dodatkowo chcemy poprawić nasze umiejętności sprawnego artykuowania swoich myśli oraz prowadzenia dyskusji programistycznej.

event.speaker: Paulien van Alst
event.title: RotterdamJUG (Java User Group)
event.subject: Kotlin workshop
event.description: In this workshop, you will build a simple webservice in Kotlin and hopefully see how easy it can be to write new business functionality. No Hello, World app guaranteed! You will be developing a true microservice with real business rules. The workshop offers you to jump in at different levels: from totally new to Kotlin to the more experienced ones. The covered topics are (data) classes, collections and types (type alias), inheritance, interfaces and extension functions, coroutines and Kotlin’s interoperability with Spring.

event.speaker: Ken Kousen
event.title: DevNexus
event.subject: Kotlin: Safe, Pragmatic Interoperability on the JVM
event.description:
Kotlin is a practical language designed for the JVM. It focuses on pragmatism and safety, with an emphasis on interoperability and tool support. Kotlin is statically typed and includes null checks in the type system itself. The language runs anywhere Java does, from microservices to Android apps. This workshop will show how to use Kotlin to simplify anything you originally planned to do in Java.

Kotlin combines object-oriented programming with functional features like lambda expressions, functional types, and data classes. Since it comes from JetBrains, the company that produces the IntelliJ IDEA development environment, it’s tool support is excellent. IntelliJ even provides a Java-to-Kotlin converter to help you get started.

This presentation will cover the basic types, defining and calling functions, programming with lambdas, higher order functions, and DSLs. The goal is to give you enough background to be productive while you continue to learn and grow with the language.

event.speaker: Hadi Hariri
event.title: Czech Kotlin User Group
event.subject: Kotlin Talk s Hadim Haririm
event.description: Nový rok začínáme pěkně zostra. Opět k nám zavítá Hadi Hariri z JetBrains, se kterým jsme se potkali loni v březnu, kdy nás provedl asynchronním programováním a ukázal, jak se používá Kotlin Coroutines. Tentokrát si pro nás připravil talk Functional Programming in Kotlin. Přiblíží nám, jak efektivně využívat funkcionální programování se zaměřením na lambdy, Higher Order funkce a podobně. Po skončení talku je připraven na zvídavé otázky – využijte možnost upgradovat své skilly a zeptat se na cokoli, co vás na Kotlinu zajímá!

event.speaker: Coen Smid
event.title: Avisi Techday
event.subject: Kotlin multiplatform
event.description:
Kotlin is een programmeertaal die steeds populairder wordt. Het gebruik neemt exponentieel toe: zowel bij apps als bij serverside applicaties. Frontend Kotlin wordt langzamerhand ook opgepakt. Nu (sinds Kotlin 1.2) is Kotlin multiplatform aangekondigd en is dit beschikbaar om mee te experimenteren.

De filosofie is als volgt: schrijf applicaties voor web, desktop, backend, Android en iOS in dezelfde taal en deel de code tussen de apps. Dit heeft meerdere voordelen, waarvan we de meeste tijdens deze Techday gaan bespreken. We willen natuurlijk vooraan staan bij deze nieuwe ontwikkelingen!

event.speaker: Paweł Włodarski
event.title: Kielce JUG
event.subject: Pierwsze warsztaty z Kotlina w ramach KJUG
event.description:
Wprowadzenie do OOP i FP w Kotlinie

Tworzenie DSLi i praktyczny przykład ze Springiem

System typów w Kotlinie

event.speaker: Adrien Pessu, Martin Lacaze
event.title: Montpellier JUG
event.subject: Kotlin: Le back du futur, le codelab
event.description:
Depuis l’annonce par Google du support de Kotlin sur Android, les développeurs d'applications mobiles se sont fortement intéressés à ce langage récent. Mais "Nom de Zeus !" est-ce réservé aux développeurs mobiles ? Non, Non et Non. Kotlin tourne sur la JVM alors autant en profiter dans tous nos projets.

Viens nous rejoindre pour découvrir toutes les facettes de ton futur prochain langage préféré. À travers plusieurs exercices, tu apprendras à transformer ton vieux Java en Kotlin puis à penser directement en Kotlin pour plus de "fun" et moins de "void".

event.speaker: Oleg Semen
event.title: Lviv Kotlin User Group
event.subject: Sliced by whole. Little advanture at multiplutform world

event.speaker: Marharyta Nedzelska
event.title: Lviv Kotlin User Group
event.subject: Kotlin: a lazy language for lazy people

event.speaker: Dmitrij Zaitzev
event.title: Lviv Kotlin User Group
event.subject: Drugs vs Money or Idiomatic DI with Kotlin

event.speaker: William Cook
event.title: Austin Kotlin Meetup
event.subject: Kotlin Coroutines
event.description: Start the new year by learning about the big feature of Kotlin 1.3, coroutines. Coroutines are an important language feature to understand, because they define how we accomplish asynchronous work in Kotlin.

event.speaker: Andrew Arnott
event.title: Kotlin Waterloo P2P
event.subject: Lambda with Receiver
event.description: Andrew will demonstrate how Kotlin lambdas are more capable and efficient than Java lambdas. He will also demonstrate how lambdas with receiver enable higher levels of code re-use than Java.

event.speaker: Alexander Nozik
event.title: Kotlin Moscow User Group
event.subject: Работа с TornadoFX в Kotlin-стиле
event.description: Александр Нозик, старший научный сотрудник института ядерных исследований РАН и руководитель научной группы МФТИ, представит обзор возможностей JavaFX в целом и TornadoFX в частности. Будет продемонстрирована работа с TornadoFX в Kotlin-стиле. Также будет демо 3D-визуализации и мультиплатформенного использования TornadoFX и JS.

event.speaker: Ilmir Usmanov
event.title: Kotlin Moscow User Group
event.subject: Kotlin Coroutines
event.description: Ильмир Усманов, разработчик компилятора Kotlin из JetBrains, расскажет о корутинах - как они устроены внутри, какие преобразования делает компилятор, чтобы синхронный код превратить в асинхронный, как на низком уровне реализованы корутины и что на самом деле делают функции suspendCoroutine и resume.

event.speaker: Kevin Galligan
event.title: GDG DevFest Florida
event.subject: Kotlin Multiplatform in Production
event.description: Kotlin Multiplatform tooling, language, and libraries have been emerging rapidly since mid-2018, and some major applications are launching into production. As Kotlin Multiplatform enters the mainstream, it will become increasingly valuable for mobile developers to understand what it is, how to think about shared architecture, what the status of the community currently is, and what to watch for updates on where the ecosystem goes in the future.

event.speaker: Ian Thomas
event.title: GDG DevFest Florida
event.subject: Exploring Kotlin Multiplatform
event.description: Developing for multiple platforms is expensive and requires multiple disciplines. Kotlin Multiplatform provides a sane, cheap, and fast method to target multiple environments with the same codebase. Leveraging direct compilation to target environments, Kotlin Multiplatform can save you time and money sharing your business logic between your target platforms. By using a common build tool, you also save considerable learning costs typically associated with writing platform native code. In this talk, we will explore these possibilities and demonstrate how a single multiplatform project can be deployed to multiple target environments.

event.speaker: Sam Edwards
event.title: GDG DevFest Florida
event.subject: DIY Dependency Injection with Kotlin
event.description: Dependency Injection seems like this SUPER complex topic that only the most senior developers understand. At the end of the day, it’s just “inversion of control” where instances of objects/classes are provided to you, instead of created by you. Kotlin’s language features allow us to do this concisely, without a library, and in this talk I’ll show you how to DO IT YOURSELF. This talk will demystify dependency injection and help you understand the huge benefits it provides for testing, maintainability and modularity.

event.speaker: Alexander Nosik, Ilnur Usmanov
event.title: Kotlin Moscow User Group
event.subject: Новогодний Kotlin - JavaFX, TornadoFX и корутины
event.description:
Будет продемонстрирована работа с TornadoFX в Kotlin-стиле. Также будет демо 3D-визуализации и мультиплатформенного использования TornadoFX и JS.

корутины - как они устроены внутри, какие преобразования делает компилятор, чтобы синхронный код превратить в асинхронный, как на низком уровне реализованы корутины и что на самом деле делают функции suspendCoroutine и resume.

event.speaker: Alexey Soshin
event.title: Amsterdam Java User Group
event.subject: Kotlin Design Patterns
event.description: Design patterns are just missing language features? In this talk we'll cover how different design patterns from "Gang of Four" are applied in Kotlin. Which are built in, which are easy to implement, and also some that are not necessary now

event.speaker: Tom Prior
event.title: Kotlin Limerick User Group
event.subject: Introducing Kotlin
event.description: This talk will be an intro talk to the Kotlin Limerick group and also to Kotlin itself and its ecosystem. It will give a high level overview of the language all the exciting things that are happening in the Kotlin ecosystem from Kotin on the JVM to Kotlin Native.

event.speaker: Tiernan Scully
event.title: Kotlin Limerick User Group
event.subject: Migrating from Java to Kotlin in Enterprise
event.description: This talk will focus on how Teckro moved from using Java 8 to Kotlin in our spring boot microservices platform. We'll touch on how it happened, the benefits gained by switching and the lessons we learned along the way.

event.speaker: Sean McQuillan
event.title: Twin Cities Kotlin User Group
event.subject: Kotlin Coroutines
event.description: Kotlin coroutines are a new way to manage async operations on Android. Stable with Kotlin 1.3, now is a great time to explore using coroutines in your app. In this talk, you'll learn about the history of coroutines, how they work in Kotlin, and effective patterns for using coroutines on Android. The talk will also cover how to avoid common pitfalls and mistakes with using coroutines. After this talk you will have a good understanding of Kotlin coroutines and how to effectively use them on Android!

event.speaker: Sean Massie
event.title: Kotlin Portland User Group
event.subject: Kotlin, standing on the shoulders of Giants.
event.description: This talk will be a discussion on the wonders of Java and what Kotlin has done to build on them.

event.speaker: Coen Smid
event.title: Avisi Techdays
event.subject: Kotlin Multiplatform
event.description:
Kotlin is a booming language. Its usage is skyrocketing in both apps and serverside applications. Frontend Kotlin is also emerging. And now (since Kotlin 1.2) Kotlin multiplatform has been announced and is currently in experimental. The philosophy: Write web, desktop, backend, Android and iOS apps in the same language and share code between your apps.

There are lots of advantages to this, many of which will be discussed during this Techday. Of course, we want to be at the front of this new development!

So software developers, come and play. You will be supplied with a working base project, the knowledge to use it and lots of sparring partners and will build an application during the hands-on.

event.speaker: Mads Bjerg Frandsen
event.title: Kotlin Copenhagen
event.subject: Sequential applications using Coroutines
event.description: This is a demonstration of how Coroutines can be used as a tool to describe your application as one sequential flow. We will go over the general architecture of an experimental application running on the JVM and Android.

event.speaker: Rafael Toledo
event.title: Kotlin Meetup - São Paulo
event.subject: Convertendo um app Android para Kotlin Gradle DSL

event.speaker: Ryan Batchelder
event.title: Kotlin Office Hours
event.subject: Adopting Kotlin at a 100 Year Old Insurance Company
event.description: The path to Kotlin adoption is different for everyone, and at an enterprise with deeply rooted tech, changing the primary programming language away from Java can be tough. This talk will dig into what our path looked like and how our team culture has grown around Kotlin, as well as things that we’ve learned along the way.

event.speaker: Sergey Alekhin
event.title: Kotlin Moscow
event.subject: Бэкенд и работа с данными через JOOQ

event.speaker: Wolfram Rittmeyer
event.title: Bielefelder Kotlin User Group
event.subject: Exploring Coroutines in Kotlin
event.description: Seit etwas mehr als einem Jahr sind Kotlin Coroutines als experimentelles Feature erhältlich. Mit Kotlin 1.3 wurden sie jüngst in den offiziellen Sprachkern aufgenommen. In diesem Talk geht Wolfram darauf ein, welche Probleme sie lösen und was dabei zu beachten ist.

event.speaker: Alexander Podkhalyuzin, Roman Belov
event.title: Kotlin user group Berlin
event.subject: Kotlin Mutliplatform, reality and future plans
event.description:
One of the most successful multiplatform technologies is JVM, however, mobile platforms gave us new challenges, which nobody solved yet in a decent way.

In this talk, we'll show you current possibilities of sharing Kotlin code between Android and iOS. It is quite new technology, so a lot of possibilities are open to you, not only for creating new apps in Kotlin but inventing new popular cross-platform libraries and we'll show how to achieve it as well. And for the talk final, we'll share some future possibilities about making a fullstack application using Kotlin and having common code between backend, frontend, and mobile apps. As part of the whole talk we will take a look into Kotlin/Native basics as it's default backend for iOS apps.

event.speaker: Thomas Sammons
event.title: Kotlin user group Berlin
event.subject: A Co-Platform Pairing Experience
event.description:
How different really is it to write a native iOS app compared with a native Android app? Are these platforms just different sides of the same coin?

This will be a recounting of the experience of pair programming between iOS and Android. How we went about doing it, the good, bad and the ugly and some interesting insights we had along the way.

event.speaker: Ash Davies
event.title: Kotlin user group Berlin
event.subject: RxJava & Coroutines: A Practical Analysis
event.description:
Kotlin has taken the Android world by storm, and is quickly becoming the most popular language, with coroutines approaching stability, does it make sense to replace your RxJava implementations for Coroutines?

Despite the hype, it may not make sense to jump on the bandwagon just yet, with RxJava having already proven its stability and usefulness, and in many cases the comparison between the two frameworks showing that they simply fit different purposes.

In this talk, you can learn how you can utilise the strengths of each framework, how to correctly choose the best solution for the requirements of your project, whether it may be beneficial to migrate or run them concurrently, and how you can start doing so for your project.

event.speaker: Adrián Bukros
event.title: Kotlin Budapest User Group
event.subject: Kotlin Multiplatform for Android and iOS
event.description: In this presentation Adrian is going to guide you through a working example (with networking and JSON parsing) where you can share your business logic between Android and iOS with the help of Kotlin Multiplatform.

event.speaker: Ádám Arold
event.title: Kotlin Budapest User Group
event.subject: Tips for writing Kotlin libraries
event.description: In this talk we'll explore some of the minor but significant intricacies of developing libraries for Kotlin, including multiplatform projects.

event.speaker: Jochen Traunecker
event.title: Kotlin User Group Stuttgart
event.subject: Polyglot backends with Kotlin and Ballerina

event.speaker: Christian Rolf
event.title: Sydney Kotlin User Group
event.subject: Kotlin Collections vs Java Streams
event.description: The Kotlin Collections API is great for processing complex data structures with readable code. But what’s the performance impact compared to using Java Streams? This talk will cover how to avoid the obvious pitfalls and when to chose readability over performance.

event.speaker: Shinoo Goyal
event.title: Sydney Kotlin User Group
event.subject: Exploring Kotlin Functions - Let’s have some fun()
event.description: The goal of this talk is learning about Kotlin functions and how they differ from the ones in Java. The discussion is around variety of scopes offered by Kotlin functions and variations on how they can be invoked. In addition, we will also take a look at lambdas and reified type parameters.

event.speaker: Simon Wirtz
event.title: Kotlin User Group Düsseldorf
event.subject: Coroutines - Simple Concurrency with Kotlin
event.description:
The concept of a coroutine is fairly old already. In the 1960s, computer scientists began describing it, and since then, multiple languages have incorporated coroutines as a tool for writing asynchronous code.

This talk will give an overview of Kotlin's approach to coroutines and how they help you structure your code.

Let's see what coroutines are, how they look like and how they support us in writing concurrent code for the JVM, JavaScript and other platforms.

It has never been a better time to get started with Kotlin coroutines as JetBrains has just released them in a 1.0 version.

event.speaker: Tomasz Godzik
event.title: Kraków Kotlin User Group
event.subject: Could Gradle be statically-typed? Meet build.gradle.kts
event.description: In this talk we will try to introduce you to Gradle build tool and how you can get it working using Kotlin. We will try to show how you can benefit from using a statically typed language for your project builds.

event.speaker: Jon Pretty
event.title: Kraków Kotlin User Group
event.subject: A Fresh Approach to Compiling JVM Languages with Fury
event.description:
Java and Scala's open-source ecosystem faces several challenges. Writing and maintaining build configurations is too difficult, and publishing is even harder, coming with additional friction of having to support an increasing multiplicity of targets targets.

But worse, this workflow puts a burden on a few key people in the open-source community to publish their libraries quickly so that their downstream users can publish theirs, and it can take months for some projects to be published. How is it that the multi-billion-dollar industry has become so dependent on so few people?

I will introduce Fury, a fast, source-based dependency manager and build tool for JVM-based languages which aspires to radically disrupt the ecosystem for the better. Fury defines builds as static data, not code, making reasoning about them simple and fast. Fury facilitates a new, distributed and version-controlled ecosystem where publishing is as simple as tagging a signed commit. And builds can be external to projects, so there's no need to impose Fury upon any existing developers who are happy with their current build setup.

The utopia we are striving for is a new, fluid and versatile ecosystem in which developers are liberated to publish more easily and frequently, and where it becomes easier for anyone to make contributions to open-source projects.

event.speaker: Serdar Cinar
event.title: Kotlin.amsterdam
event.subject: Contract Programming
event.description: Kotlin 1.3 introduced built-in support for Contracts to improve smart casting. In this talk, we will discover the "Contract Programming" principles and how to implement them in Kotlin. Although it is still immature and has limited capabilities, we will discuss the use cases and potential of Contracts in Kotlin’s future.

event.speaker: Alexey Soshin
event.title: Kotlin.amsterdam
event.subject: Design Patterns with Kotlin
event.description: "Design Patterns" by Gang of Four is one of the best known books about software. Some declare that those design patterns are obsolete, though. Are they? In this talk we'll cover some of them, and discuss whether they make sense in the Kotlin world.

event.speaker: Jason Mauer
event.title: Kotlin Portland User Group
event.subject: Kotlin + Android = Crazy Delicious
event.description: Kotlin is the new hotness in Android development since Google announced its official support at last year’s IO conference. We’ll be going over the benefits of moving to Kotlin for Android, as well as tips and tricks for Android developers getting up to speed with the language.

event.speaker: Tadej Slamic
event.title: Oslo Kotlin Meetup
event.subject: Kotlin/Native, a brief introduction
event.description: Kotlin/Native is all the hype these days. In this brief introduction, we'll cover the Kotlin/Native basics and go through a few examples on how to write multiplatform code. We'll see code that runs on Android, as well as iOS, and discuss the niceties and limitations of this new and exciting technology.

event.speaker: José Dimas
event.title: Facilito Talks Online #3
event.subject: Kotlin para el 2019
event.description: José es Google Developer Expert en Android y Kotlin, además de tutor en CódigoFacilito. Para esta edición nos tiene un tema con las novedades que le esperan a Kotlin en el año que viene, en sus propias palabras, no es predecir el futuro, son cosas que ya se anunciaron.

event.speaker: Florina Muntenescu
event.title: DevFest onAir
event.subject: Shaping your app’s architecture with Kotlin and Architecture Components
event.description:
Many apps began adopting Kotlin and Android Architecture Components atthe same time. While ostensibly quite different, the interplay of these two changes ends up heavily influencing each other.

Plaid is an open source example of material design concepts. It has a complex functionality but had a large amount of technical debt. We took the challenge of refactoring the app, following the Android Guide to App Architecture, while simultaneously converting the app to Kotlin—while keeping the existing functionality, fixing broken API integrations and adding new ones.

The Guide to App Architecture provided a good starting point for creating lean, isolated classes. Kotlin features like delegates, high order functions and lambdas, sealed classes and others, end up shaping much of the architecture of the app. This talk covers the architecture lessons learned while converting Plaid to Kotlin and integrating Architecture Components.

event.speaker: Giorgio Natili
event.title: Seattle Android Developers
event.subject: Funtastic Kotlin
event.description:
Kotlin was on the market for a while when Google announced its official support in Android over one year ago. This announcement consolidated an already rich user base and brought new enthusiasm to the language making it a de-facto standard tool for Android development.

Kotlin supports both the object-oriented and functional programming paradigms. Even more, its support for high-order functions, extension functions, scoping functions, lambdas, and immutable values can revolutionize the way Android apps get developed.

In Kotlin you define a function with the fun keyword, and I have to say it, no better choice for a language keyword!

During this talk, I will show you all the peculiarities of Kotlin's functions and drive you through the transformation that you can apply to an existing Android code base and make it functional, testable, and, even more, easy to read.

event.speaker: Antonis Lilis
event.title: Kotlin Athens
event.subject: An introduction to Kotlin Coroutines
event.description: Coroutines that fascinated devs from its early beta have graduated the experimental phase and are now stable 🎓. Coroutines provide a way to write asynchronous code sequentially making multithreaded programming more debuggable and maintainable. In this presentation Antonis will try to guide you through the main features of Coroutines that make it so special.

event.speaker: Jolanda Verhoef
event.title: Kotlin Belgium User Group
event.subject: Introduction to Android programming with Kotlin.
event.description:
Introduction to Android programming with Kotlin by Jolanda from Coolblue! Google officially supports Kotlin as a programming language for Android Development. So if you know Kotlin, you might as well become an Android Developer!

During this evening we will dive into the world of Android. Jolanda will first explain how programming for Android devices differs from programming for servers. Then we will follow one of Google's Codelabs, which will walk you through creating your very first Android App.

event.speaker: Louis CAD
event.title: AndroidRennes
event.subject: Escaping Callback Hell with coroutines
event.description: Les coroutines, c'est stable depuis quelques jours dans Kotlin 1.3, mais ça fait depuis la version 1.1 que des gens se sont fait les dents dessus avec la version expérimentale, qui a fait des merveilles en production ! Dans Android, il y a un tas de callbacks et d'événements asynchrones, ce qui conduit facilement au plus bas de l'enfer : les callback hells. Un callback hell, c'est une pâte à base de vieux spaghettis collants, que vous devez manger à chaque fois que vous remettez des pâtes pour rajouter des fonctionnalités ou effectuer de la maintenance. Certains diététiciens préconisent de transformer ça en jolis streams de spaghettis en passant à la programmation réactive, mais cela demande beaucoup d'effort quand il s'agit d'arrondir les coins pour faire un cercle. Entre temps, les chercheurs de chez JetBrains et leurs disciples ont mis au point des pâtes qui se cuisinent beaucoup plus facilement dans tous les sens : les coroutines. Sans métaphore, les coroutines permettent d'avoir un code asynchrone et séquentiel en même temps. Dans cette session de live coding, vous verrez comment il est possible avec moins de code de faire plein de choses routinières, comme accéder à une base de données Room hors du main thread, filmer avec l'API Camera2 en 5 lignes de code (dont 4 lignes pour le try/catch), faire des appels à une API/webservice, et attendre n'importe quel callback sans jamais attaquer la lisibilité de votre code.

event.speaker: Dennis Geurts, Tom Sabel
event.title: Luminis Rotterdam Brain Upgrade
event.subject: Kotlin en Android
event.description:
Découverte : La programmation orienté objet en Kotlin : 20 minutes en livecoding pour découvrir la syntaxe et les outils proposés.

Confirmé : Tests unitaires, une bonne recette. Comment rendre vos tests unitaires plus lisible et concis avec Kotlin.

event.speaker: Ilya Matveyev
event.title: JUGNsk
event.subject: Kotlin вообще и Native в частности
event.description: Наверняка многие слышали о таком языке для JVM, как Котлин. Однако далеко не все знают, что он также компилируется в JavaScript или в нативный код для различных платформ. В этом докладе мы постараемся пролить свет на поддержку мультиплатформенных проектов, а также расскажем о том, как мы компилируем Котлин в машинный код, какие сложности при этом встречаются и какие возможности дает это пользователю.

event.speaker: Janibek Marshal
event.title: JDrinkUp Almaty
event.subject: Почему Android разработчики переходят на Kotlin

event.speaker: Toshihiro Yagi
event.title: Kotlin Fest 2018
event.subject: Kotlin コルーチンを 理解しよう

event.speaker: Anton Arhipov
event.title: Advanced Java Estonia
event.subject: Kotlin DSL in 60 minutes
event.description: Learn how to create type-safe and statically typed DSLs in Kotlin. The session starts with an introduction to DSL related Kotlin language features. Next, we create a simple DSL in a live coding session and then continue adding expressiveness and language features. We cover a number of examples, like JSON or XML builder's, data binding, configuration & template engines

event.speaker: Nick Capurso
event.title: 360|AnDev July 2018
event.subject: Kotlin Coroutines: An Intro to Practical Use on Android
event.description:
Asynchronous programming has always been a challenging problem for Android developers. Any good solution has to gracefully handle errors, cancellation, chaining multiple actions together, handle thread swapping, and much more.

Kotlin’s coroutines are yet another option for asynchronous programming. However, unlike other popular contenders, coroutines meet all the previously mentioned requirements out-of-the-box, have a gentler learning curve, and don’t require you to write an absurd amount of boilerplate.

That said, learning any new asynchronous solution takes time and often comes with a period of trial-and-error until you have all the nuances figured out. Get a jumpstart on coroutines:

(1) Lessen the learning curve by getting the subtleties of coroutines out of the way early (2) Learn how to work coroutines into an existing app: easy places to start transitioning, interop with existing libraries, and reusing existing threading constructs (3) Learn how to easily support error handling, cancellation, and task chaining (4) Learn how to unit test coroutines

Get a head start on coroutines in your apps and easily write, test, and maintain asynchronous code like never before!

event.speaker: Oluwasegun Famisa
event.title: 360|AnDev July 2018
event.subject: Kotlin, Beyond the Basics
event.description:
In this talk, we will look at how you should not do things with Kotlin. For example, we will talk about misusing scoping functions like “let”, “run”, “apply”, etc. and learn the right time to use which one while not overusing them. We will also talk about interoperability between Kotlin and Java. We will look at how not to do things when building APIs that may be consumed in Java – things like top-level constant declaration vs constants within companion objects, making use Jvm* annotations in Kotlin vs not using them.

We will also talk about platform types and the potential harm they pose when calling Java code from Kotlin. We will also address another commonly overlooked topic – the fact that Kotlin encourages a new paradigm of programming where you’re not thinking in terms of steps (imperative) but rather, in terms of functions applied to parameters (functional programming) and we still find ourselves doing things the wrong way.

event.speaker: Joshua Lamson
event.title: 360|AnDev July 2018
event.subject: Custom Drawing with Canvas in Kotlin
event.description:
When you’re creating a new View to display some complex data, it’s easy for the number of View objects you’re using to get out of control. Between elaborate shapes, shaders/colors, and text in specific places and orientations, using only Android Views and layouts can turn your layout into a dense, complicated mess. Luckily, there’s a better way to add all your customizations. What you need is a blank Canvas! (Literally, android.graphics.Canvas).

In this session, we’ll delve into the details of using a Canvas to display anything you need in a truly custom way, explaining it all through simple examples written in Kotlin. You’ll leave this talk knowing how override the behavior of View, ViewGroup, and Drawable to draw custom shapes, paths, and text on the Canvas.

event.speaker: Joshua Lamson
event.title: From Kotlin Vienna
event.subject: Custom Drawing with Canvas in Kotlin
event.description:
When you’re creating a new View to display some complex data, it’s easy for the number of View objects you’re using to get out of control. Between elaborate shapes, shaders/colors, and text in specific places and orientations, using only Android Views and layouts can turn your layout into a dense, complicated mess. Luckily, there’s a better way to add all your customizations. What you need is a blank Canvas! (Literally, android.graphics.Canvas).

In this session, we’ll delve into the details of using a Canvas to display anything you need in a truly custom way, explaining it all through simple examples written in Kotlin. You’ll leave this talk knowing how override the behavior of View, ViewGroup, and Drawable to draw custom shapes, paths, and text on the Canvas.

event.speaker: Shady Selim
event.title: GDG Alexandria
event.subject: Kotlin Updates in from the Google I/O
event.description: Will summarize all the Kotlin talks and updates that was mentioned in the Google I/O 2018

event.speaker: Sriyank Siddhartha
event.title: GDG Bhubaneswar
event.subject: The Power of Kotlin Language
event.description: Leverage the power of Koltin with its amazing features and get a sneak peak of its application in Android.

event.speaker: Chandra Sekhar Nayak
event.title: BangaloreJUG
event.subject: Introduction to Kotlin
event.description: An introduction to Kotlin for Java developers. This is presented at BangaloreJUG meetup's June 2018 meet.

event.speaker: Tomás Hanley
event.title: Dublin Kotlin Meetup
event.subject: Intro to Kotlin & starting the Kotlin Koans
event.description: We'll be starting with a presentation on Kotlin, what it is, why you should use it, and why we're passionate about adopting it!

event.speaker: Roberto Orgiu
event.title: GDG DevFest Levante
event.subject: Kotlin 101
event.description: Benvenuti nell'universo Android! Roberto Orgiu, GDE Android ci introdurrà Kotlin il nuovo linguaggi di programmazione di IntelliJ e promosso come linguaggio principale su Android insieme a Java

event.speaker: Kevin Galligan
event.title: .droidconSF
event.subject: Kotlin Multiplatform In Production
event.description:
Kotlin Native, with the ability to produce iOS code, was announced at KotlinConf 2017. With rapid progress on the runtime and tools, and intense community interest, several major architectural libraries have been released. KotlinConf 2018 will definitely see significant releases both, in both libraries and tools, and likely an official v1 of Kotlin Native.

2019 will be the year of significant application releases with a shared architectural base, powered by Kotlin multiplatform. This talk will be about the framework, how it compares (favorably) to other options, the current state of the ecosystem, and where developers eager to get involved in significant open source contributions can get started.

event.speaker: Juliano Moraes
event.title: .droidconSF
event.subject: Netflix's componentization architecture with RxJava + Kotlin
event.description:
Recently we rewrote the Netflix's player UI using a new architecture that allows great reusability, testability and extendability.

This talk is about our journey from a monolithic fragment to several independent and reusable components and how it is helping us to move fast with our AB tests.

event.speaker: Brent Watson
event.title: .droidconSF
event.subject: Advanced Kotlin
event.description: If you want to up your Kotlin game, come check out some advanced language features. Some of the things we'll cover are: delegates, covariance/contravariance, tailrec, sealed classes, kotlin's reflection API, coroutines, and more.

event.speaker: Cecilia Castillo
event.title: .droidconSF
event.subject: If your code looks like it's Kotlin & quacks like it's Kotlin, then it probably is Swift.

event.speaker: Israel Ferrer Camacho
event.title: .droidconSF
event.subject: From Effective Java to Effective Kotlin

event.speaker: Joaquim Verges
event.title: .droidconSF
event.subject: Quick and clean prototypes that scale with Helium: a reactive MVP framework in Kotlin

event.speaker: Roman Elizarov
event.title: Goto Conference
event.subject: Fresh Async With Kotlin
event.description:
Asynchronous programming is on the rise. Modern software systems are connected and constantly communicating. Programming languages are adding some form of asynchronous programming like async/await. However, Kotlin had taken a fresh approach to this problem with Kotlin Coroutines.

In this talk, we’ll study various approaches to asynchronous programming, their evolution, differences and similarities. We’ll see the problem with the traditional async/await approach that is based on futures/promises and how the Kotlin’s solution that is based on concepts of coroutines and continuations is giving us safer and easier programming model.

event.speaker: Roman Elizarov
event.title: Goto Conference
event.subject: Asynchronous Programming with Kotlin
event.description: This workshop covers asynchronous programming in Kotlin using coroutines. It starts with basics of asynchronous programming and its differences from blocking code and introduces concepts of suspending functions and coroutines. Dealing with the ecosystem of blocking code on JVM is covered in depth as well as best practices for managing cancellation of asynchronous operations. The workshop also covers more advanced topics of concurrent decomposition of work via futures, deep dive into coroutine contexts and includes an overview of Communication Sequential Process (CSP) approach and channels.

event.speaker: Kevin Most
event.title: Øredev
event.subject: Idiomatic Interop with Kotlin
event.description:
One of Kotlin's most valuable features is its 100% Java interop

However, your clean Java code might not look so clean from Kotlin, and vice versa

We will discuss strategies to write code in either language, to be consumed in either language, that is safe, elegant, and idiomatic

We will also touch on Kotlin's interop story for other targets (common, JS, and native) and what you can do there

event.speaker: Simon Harrer
event.title: Øredev
event.subject: Domain-driven Design with Kotlin
event.description:
You will learn about domain-driven design and its tactical design.

You will learn about implementing a tactical design in Kotlin using also lesser known language features.

You will learn a little bit about the rules in dungeons and drago

event.speaker: Marharyta Nedzelska
event.title: Devoxx Ukraine 2018
event.subject: Domain-driven Design with Kotlin
event.description: Microservice architecture is now a huge trend. All big organizations with millions of users are doing microservices. This means they have lots of channels of communication between services and need to send and get much data. At some point, you can find yourself in a situation where your current approach doesn’t provide you with efficient communications, you pay more, wait for more, lose more etc. Maybe it’s time to look at gRPC… In this talk, we will cover the basics of gRPC, protocol buffers, and its usage. We will try to understand its pros and cons and where this approach could be used. We will also compare this approach with the alternatives. The most interesting about this talk is that we will have lots of practice. We will learn how to write .proto files, how to make effective communication between your microservices, and of course, write much code (in Kotlin)

event.speaker: Pamela Hill
event.title: GDG DevFest South Africa
event.subject: Level up in Kotlin
event.description: Kotlin has taken the Android world by storm since its official support in 2017. Many Android developers are coding or have at least an active interest in Kotlin. This talk aims to help Android developers level up their Kotlin skills, focussing on intermediate/expert language features such as coroutines, DSLs, and libraries/frameworks such as Koin for dependency injection, and Spek for testing.

event.speaker: Hadi Tok
event.title: GDG DevFest Istanbul
event.subject: RxJava ve Kotlin Coroutines, Kullanim senaryolari
event.description: RxJava bir çok kullanımı olan güçlü bir araç. Asenkron işlem ve fonksiyonel programlamanın bir çok öğesini kullanıma sunuyor. Fakat Kotlin fonksiyonel programlama özelliklerini şimdiden, Asenkron işlemleri kolaylaştıran ve ucuzlaştıran Coroutine'leri 1.3 versiyonu ile sağlıyor. RxJava ve Kotlinin bu özelliklerinin karşılaştıracağım.

event.speaker: Enrique López Mañas
event.title: AndroidTO
event.subject: Kotlin/Native for Multiplatform Development
event.description:
Reliable multiplatform development has been the Holy Grail for Mobile Developers since its inception. Many frameworks did appear and disappear. Kotlin/Native has come strongly, and since it is still in Beta version there are some caveats about this. Is Kotlin/Native reliable for my app? Is it production-ready?

Come to this talk to learn what Kotlin/Native can do for you.

event.speaker: Francisco Estévez García
event.title: AndroidTO 2018
event.subject: Simple dependency management in Kotlin
event.description: In this talk we will discover how we can use just Kotlin features to inject dependencies through our codebase. Using this novel approach we'll introduce the concept of Type Classes, a unit of abstraction and configuration used to architect apps and libraries.

event.speaker: Zan Markan
event.title: AndroidTO 2018
event.subject: The State of The Kotlin Ecosystem
event.description: In early 2018 I ran a survey of the global Kotlin ecosystem. My goal was to learn how developers use and adopt Kotlin - either in work or side projects, or just for playing around, and what are some of the most popular resources for learning it. The survey was a great success, and gained over 2000 responses in total! The results are meant to become a resource for the Kotlin community. Something we can all look at for interesting insights that will also help drive adoption of Kotlin in our teams and organisations. To give you a taster, here’s a few questions I asked in the survey: How big is Android as a proportion of all Kotlin developers Are people happy naming libraries and tooling with K What are the favourite features of the language What kind of DSLs are people building with Kotlin and for what use-cases In my talk will answer all these questions, and more. But be warned, some answers might surprise you.

event.speaker: Svyatoslav Scherbina
event.title: AndroidTO 2018
event.subject: Using Kotlin to share code between iOS and Android
event.description: This talk is devoted to using Kotlin to share code between Android and iOS. It also covers Kotlin features and evolution making this possible and convenient. Kotlin Multiplatform Programming is a technology for multiplatform programming in Kotlin. It supports combining both common and platform-specific code in a single codebase with proper tooling enabled. Kotlin/Native is a technology for compiling Kotlin code to native binaries. Kotlin code has seamless interoperability with native platform (e.g. iOS) in this case. The speaker will describe how Kotlin/Native works, what is supported and what is not.

event.speaker: Marcin Moskała
event.title: AndroidTO 2018
event.subject: Superpowers of Property Delegation
event.description: Let's dive into possibilities that Kotlin delegation gives. Let’s discover property delegation and understand its superpowers.

event.speaker: Nikita Koval
event.title: Joker 2018
event.subject: Как устроены каналы в корутинах в Kotlin
event.description:
В отличие от классического многопоточного программирования с манипулированием разделяемой памятью, корутины общаются друг с другом при помощи каналов. Канал позволяет одной корутине отправить элемент, а другой — получить его. При этом данные операции могут быть синхронизированы, и отправитель может ждать получателя и наоборот.

В этом докладе мы поговорим об устройстве каналов в различных языках и библиотеках, о разработанном в Kotlin алгоритме и узнаем, кто круче: Kotlin или Go.

event.speaker: Evgeny Mandrikov
event.title: Joker 2018
event.subject: Java 4..11, Kotlin, Code Coverage и их лучший друг — байткод: скандалы, интриги, расследования
event.description:
Знаете ли вы, что внутри ваших .class-файлов? А готовы поспорить? Давайте повеселимся, исследуя конструкции байт-кода, и изучим, как различные компиляторы (Java/Kotlin) и их версии, включая недавно выпущенный javac 11, преобразуют ваш исходный код.

p>Наши исследования будут основаны на деталях реализации самого популярного инструмента для анализа покрытия Java-кода тестами — JaCoCo, чья недавно выпущенная версия находит в байт-коде и отфильтровывает вспомогательные конструкции, генерируемые компиляторами, которые в противном случае требуют зачастую сложных и ненужных ухищрений, чтобы добиться полного покрытия кода.

event.speaker: Anton Keks
event.title: Mobius 2018
event.subject: Kotlin puzzlers, Vol. 2
event.description:
Kotlin is a marvelous language that makes programming on the JVM fun again. During the design phase of the language, it was said that Kotlin specifically tried to avoid some of the most famous Java Puzzlers. However, having so many advanced features, it cannot avoid introducing puzzlers of its own. This talk will present some of the more interesting nuances of syntax or language features with the help of small puzzler programs letting the audience guess their behavior. The mystery will then be revealed with an explanation in a fun way.

Having received an overwhelmingly good feedback from the previous version, Anton is ready with a set of completely new puzzlers to entertain you among all these really serious talks!

event.speaker: Svyatoslav Scherbina
event.title: Mobius 2018
event.subject: Using Kotlin to share code between Android and iOS
event.description:
This talk's main topic is how you can use Kotlin to share code between Android and iOS. We will also cover Kotlin platform development trends that make this easy and possible.

Kotlin Multiplatform Programming technology allows you to combine common and platform-specific code in a single codebase while also supporting tooling for this kind of development model. We'll see how this looks and discuss why it should be like this and not the other way around.

Kotlin/Native technology allows you to compile Kotlin into native code while also giving you an option to interact seamlessly with native platform (iOS, for example). We'll discuss what, why and how does (and does not) work.

event.speaker: Daniel González Reina
event.title: Dublin Kotlin User Group
event.subject: Create a Kotlin-React App
event.description: In this meetup we'll learn how to create a web app using the Kotlin wrappers for React. We'll see how to take advantage of Kotlin features to write expressive code that will compile to a React application.

event.speaker: Marie Katrine Ekeberg
event.title: Oslo Kotlin Meetup
event.subject: Testing in Kotlin and YOU
event.description: What options do you have for testing your code in Kotlin? Some people will probably just jump straight to JUnit as a testing framework, but did you know you that Spek offers an alternative approach with a domain specific language (DSL) for tests? Your choice of tools doesn't stop here. You have alternative assertion libraries, mocking frameworks and more that are different from what you may be used to in Java. The builder pattern is also even simpler in Kotlin, which make creating test data builders work like a charm. We will look at these topics and more! With examples ranging from small utility classes to integration tests with Spring.

event.speaker: Javier Moreno Aleman, Tammy Tyberg
event.title: New York Kotlin Meetup
event.subject: NYC Subway Sign with Kotlin and Raspberry Pi
event.description: A few months ago we were looking through a gift guide and saw one of those nice-looking, real-time Subway signs that you put on a coffee table or a bookshelf. We decided to get one, then saw the price (+$300) and thought, "Wait a minute, we're pretty sure we can just build this for less money." So after grabbing one of the many Raspberry Pis lying around the office, and with Kotlin as the weapon of choice, we embarked on a new project: Your own personal subway sign for (way) under $300.

event.speaker: Ryan Cooke
event.title: New York Kotlin Meetup
event.subject: Building Backend Microservices in Kotlin
event.description: Ryan will describe how Kotlin has gone from a hackathon experiment to the language of choice for backend service development at N26. He will present thoughtful strategies on how to build adoption based on learnings from false-starts introducing other languages to the stack. And with a bottoms-up approach, Kotlin eventually advanced into his firm's Android applications. N26 is now an active member in the Kotlin community in Europe and is focused on applying emerging features such as coroutines to their event driven systems.
